Title: Thalamic and temporal cortex input to medial prefrontal cortex in rhesus monkeys
Abstract:
To determine the source of thalamic input to the medial aspect of the prefrontal cortex, we injected retrograde tracers (wheat germ agglutinin conjugated to horseradish peroxidase, nuclear yellow, and/or bisbenzimide) into seven medial prefrontal sites and anterograde tracers (tritiated amino acids) into six thalamic sites, in a total of nine rhesus monkeys. The results indicated that ventral precallosal and subcallosal areas 14 and 25, and the ventral, subcallosal part of area 32, all receive projections from the mediodorsal portion of the magnocellular division of the medial dorsal nucleus (MDmc). The dorsal, precallosal part of area 32 receives projections mainly from the dorsal portion of the parvocellular division of the medial dorsal nucleus (MDpc), which also provides some input to area 14. Polar area 10 receives input from both MDpc and the densocellular division of the medial dorsal nucleus (MDdc), as does supracallosal area 24. Area 24 receives additional input from the anterior medial nucleus and midline nuclei. All medial prefrontal cortical areas were also found to receive projections from a number of cortical regions within the temporal lobe, such as the temporal pole, superior temporal gyrus, and parahippocampal gyrus. Areas 24, 25, and 32 receive, in addition, input from the entorhinal cortex. Combining these results with prior anatomical and behavioral data, we conclude that medial temporal areas that are important for object recognition memory send information directly both to dorsal medial prefrontal areas 24 and 32 and to ventral medial
prefrontal areas 14 and 25. Only the latter two areas have  additional access to this information via projections from the
mediodorsal part of MDmc.

"For the cortex of the temporal lobe, we we used the nomenclature of Bonin and Bailey (1947)... We followed, in general, the cytoarchitectonic describtions used by Amaral and his colleagues (Amaral et al. 1987; Susuki et Amaral 1994), exept for the tempolar polar region, for which we have retained the designation "area TG" of von Bonin and Bailey (1947) instead of "area 36p"."

"For the cortex of the temporal lobe, we we used the nomenclature of Bonin and Bailey (1947)... @LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "When the injection was rostral to the genu of the corpus callosum, (cases 3-Bis and 5-NY)... (cases 3-NY and 1-WGA-HRP), labeled cells were observed rostrally in the dorsal half of the temporal polar area TG, and around the lip of the superior temporal sulcus (TA); more caudally, labeled neurons were found in the parahippocampal gyrus, mainly in area TH, extending slightly into the laterally adjacent area TF."
"... in case 1-WGA-HRP, the labeled cells were found in the dorsal portion of MDmc and in the central densocellular nucleus (Fig. 3)."

@Injections.Citation: "In case 2-WGA-HRP, the injection was placed in the rotral portion of supracallosal area 24."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "Labeled cells [in case 2-WGA-HRP] were locatd predominantly in the dorsal part of the anterior medial (AM) nucleus and in the midline nuclei (Fig. 5). Within the midline, labeled cells were seen in the paraventricular (Pa), central latocellular (Clc) and reuniens (Re) nuclei. Additional labeling was found in the intralaminar, central superior lateral (Csl) nucleus , as well as in MDdc and the lateral part of MDpc (not shown). No cells were found in MDmc."

@Injections.Citation: "The injection sites in cases 3-Bis and 5-NY were both located in the rostralmost part of the left prefrontal cortex, ventral to the rostral sulcus, in areas 10 and 14... in case the injection extended fartherposteriorly into area 14..."

@Injections.Citation: "In the other two cases with injections in MD (cases 4-AA and 6-AA), the injection sites were smaller and confined to the center of MDmc on the left, avoiding in particular its dorsomedial portion."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "Medially this labeling [in case 7-AA] was located in the ventral half of polar area TG and continued into the rostral part of perirhinal cortex (areas 35 and 36). Laterally, terminals were observed in inferior temporal area TE, within and medial to the fundus of the superior temporal sulcus. More caudally, labelling was found only in the central part of the entorhinal cortex (area 28). By contrast, the injections restricted to the center of MDmc (cases 4-AA and 6-AA) did not yield any terminal labeling  within these temporal cortical areas."

"Labeling [in case 4-AA] was found on the ventral and lateral surfaces of the frontal lobes in areas ... (i.e., from medial to lateral, areas 11 and 13, area 12, and areas  6, 8 and 46), but this time no label was found in areas 14, 25, and 32 on the medial wall of the frontal lobes."

@Injections.Citation: "For the two injection sites centered upon the left anterior nuclei, one (case 5-AA) was confined to the anterior dorsal (AD) and anterior ventral (AV) nuclei, involving little of the anterior medial (AM) nucleus, and entirely avoiding MD."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "When the injection site was confined to the AD and AV (case 5-AA), only the pre- and paraubiculum contained labeled neurons."

@Injections.Citation: "In the other two cases with injections in MD (cases 4-AA and 6-AA), the injection sites were smaller and confined to the center of MDmc on the left, avoiding in particular its dorsomedial portion."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "Medially this labeling [in case 7-AA] was located in the ventral half of polar area TG and continued into the rostral part of perirhinal cortex (areas 35 and 36). By contrast, the injections restricted to the center of MDmc (cases 4-AA and 6-AA) did not yield any terminal labeling  within these temporal cortical areas."

"Labeling [in case 6-AA] was found on the ventral and lateral surfaces of the frontal lobes in areas ... (i.e., from medial to lateral, areas 11 and 13, area 12, and areas  6, 8 and 46), but this time no label was found in areas 14, 25, and 32 on the medial wall of the frontal lobes."

@Injections.Citation: "Among the four injection sites centered upon MDmc, two (cases 7-AA and 9-AA) were midline sites involving most of MDmc, dorsal and ventral on both sitdes, together with the central intermedial nucleus (Cim) which seperates the two halves of MD. These injection site also enchroaches slightly  on the midline nuclei central superior (Cs), paraventricular (Pa), and central inferior (Cif) (Fig. 8A)."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "The labeled terminals covered the entire ventral portion of prefrontal cortex in both hemispheres, exept for the frontal pole (area 10). On medial walls, labeled terminals were found in area 14, the anterior and ventral part of area 25, and the ventral portion of precallosal area 32 (Fig. 8C). On ventral surface, the labeling was observed throughout areas 13 and 11 of the orbital cortex, and area 12 of the inferior convexity. Labeling continued onto the ventral portion of the lateral surface, inluding the ventral bank of the principal sulcus (ventral area 46) and within both banks of the lower limb of the arcuate sulcus  (areas 6 and 8)."

@Injections.Citation: "In case 8-AA, the injection site involved the AM and dorsal MD in addition to the anterior dorsal (AD) and anterior ventral (AV) nuclei."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "On the medial wall of the hemisphere [in case 8], labeled terminals were found principally in the posteroir and dorsal part of area 25, in area 32, and the anterior cingulate area 24. On the ventral and lateral surfaces, labeled terminals were observed in orbital areas 11 and 13 (this label extended slightly onto the laterally adjacent ara 12), as well as in the ventral bank of the principal sulcus (area 46). publication.title: Thalamic and temporal cortex input to medial prefrontal cortex in rhesus monkeys
publication.abstract:
To determine the source of thalamic input to the medial aspect of the prefrontal cortex, we injected retrograde tracers (wheat germ agglutinin conjugated to horseradish peroxidase, nuclear yellow, and/or bisbenzimide) into seven medial prefrontal sites and anterograde tracers (tritiated amino acids) into six thalamic sites, in a total of nine rhesus monkeys. The results indicated that ventral precallosal and subcallosal areas 14 and 25, and the ventral, subcallosal part of area 32, all receive projections from the mediodorsal portion of the magnocellular division of the medial dorsal nucleus (MDmc). The dorsal, precallosal part of area 32 receives projections mainly from the dorsal portion of the parvocellular division of the medial dorsal nucleus (MDpc), which also provides some input to area 14. Polar area 10 receives input from both MDpc and the densocellular division of the medial dorsal nucleus (MDdc), as does supracallosal area 24. Area 24 receives additional input from the anterior medial nucleus and midline nuclei. All medial prefrontal cortical areas were also found to receive projections from a number of cortical regions within the temporal lobe, such as the temporal pole, superior temporal gyrus, and parahippocampal gyrus. Areas 24, 25, and 32 receive, in addition, input from the entorhinal cortex. Combining these results with prior anatomical and behavioral data, we conclude that medial temporal areas that are important for object recognition memory send information directly both to dorsal medial prefrontal areas 24 and 32 and to ventral medial
prefrontal areas 14 and 25. Only the latter two areas have  additional access to this information via projections from the
mediodorsal part of MDmc.
